titleStmt.title: M54, 2 of 11. [Anon: The historians work from the outer to the inner...]. Typescript fragment, 5 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M54, 2 of 11. [The historians work from the outer to the inner...]. Typescript fragment, 2 fols.

N.B.: This is one of eleven sub-fragments identified the Berg Collection's M54. [Anon: The printing press brought the past into existence...]. Typescript fragments, unsigned and undated, 35 fols. I have determined pagination and sequencing based on subject matter. M54 as curated by the Berg Collection is available as part of 'The Digital Anon' and can be found at [LINK].

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
The historians work from the outer to the inner; from the house they infer the teant (tenant) of the house. It is the house thy (they) dwell upon; the chairs and the furniture of the house. It is as if we were told nbideen (bidden) to infer from a tweed suit, and six hats, and a fox terrier, and a
waljing (walking) stick and a c kitchen with a col (coal) fire and a servant pcalled perhaps Joan the life and woks (works) of a novelist call that wrote the and Save for and and the voice of Anon singing at the back door the English might be a dumb race, who suffered nad (and) ennjoyed in silnce (silence); a race of me rhcnats (merchants), soldiers and preists (priests) builders who left behind thm (them) stone houses, cultivated fields and vast cathedrals. but not no words. The great house is silent; Only the furniture
mains (remains), stiff and ornate, fanastic (fantastic) and uncushioned.

At for instance sat at her table writing letters. But Her letters to are letter written [illeg.] from the pulpit; as intricate involved and formal as state papers or legal documents or dyin depositons (dying depositions). She admonishes and preaches; she expresses the violence of her temper and theher violene (violence) and her suspiions (suspicions); suspicions of her soul. She is a counsellor admonishing a subordinate. She is aware expressive only of th (the) wickedness of men, the dangers and deceits of the world; and the
awfu;ness (awfulness) of her God. Greek and Latin come to her pen as easily as English. If she has to decend (descend) to the actual objec (object) a basket of starwberries (strawberries)-- it is with coircomlocution (circumlocution) and dark threats. "I have sent them by th (the) boy of my kitchen, a shrewd witted boy and prettily cachetized, but yet an untoward crafty boy..." She writes onlt (only) to

exhort "God keep us sound in the faith and send us health and a care to please God above all" Or to admonish---
"Be not speedy of speech, nor talk suddenly, but where discretion requireth, and that soberly then.... Let not Lawson, that fox, be acqaunited (acquainted) with my letters..."
Fear of man, fear of God surround them as h as with the wallsof (walls of) a dungeon. There is no gaiety, no freedom, no familairity (familiarity)
ni (in) the hose (house) she lives in. The sound of the Bible is in her
wars (words). Her prose takes its slolemn (solemn) strain. And the prose of the bible will not adapt itself to the eaxy (easy), the co oqu (colloquial) It is a garment to be put on when the mind is erect and dignified, on state oaccions (occasions).

It is because they use of the prose of the bible when they write prose that the Elizabethans are unknown to us. It They can say nothing simle (simple), nothing intimate. They are nevr (never) subtle; they are never shaded. Bright contrastd (contrasted) colours meet on their faces. Carnation and sanow (snow); ebony and gold. When we look at them we see them in their farthibgales (farthingales) and ru ffs (ruffs); young men s (men's) bodies are stiffly sewn into dohblets (doublets) and school boys faces are raised above starched collars; yong (young) women serve only to s display heavy quilted dresse (dresses) stuck about with huge pearls. The writer, to rds (towards) the end of the sicteenth cnyury (sixteenth century), was separate from his arudience (audience); but he was still closely connected with it. He was himself unspecialised, un ifferent (undifferentiated) ated. His eye was stimulated by the crimsons and gold and greens of the clothing. His ear was stimulated by the sound of words For ac (each) word was given substance and sharpness

by the speaking voice. And the l tes (lutes) and the cithersn (citherns)
have (gave) lilt and rhym (rhythm) and melody to the spoken word. His mind was full of half sung half spoekn (spoken) words; full of undifferentiated words; ol (old) words, new words; French words Latin words. No grammar bound them tightly together. They were elastic. They could stretch to any lgneth (length). They cd (could) could refelct (reflect) many colours; they could fol ow (follow) many tunes, they could be danced to, and sung to. But they could not follow the words of the speaking voice. For a moment then there is a pause on the threshold of the gre t (great) lizabethan (Elizabethan) room. The artist is not wholly writer, wholly musician, or wholly paineter (painter). xmxsxmxsmssxmxsxmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxsxmxmxmxmxmxmmx xmxmxmxmmxmxmxmxmxmxmmxmxmxm. may be ; Soenser (Spenser) may be . It seems possible that the great English art may not be the art of poetry.

The writer then came to birth with difficulty in England; for so long as familiar letters are written in Biblical prose there are limits to his freedom; a barrier between the sayable and the unsayable. He is in being; for the printing press has given him a name; but still unspecialised, undifferentiated. The artist is not wholly
write (writer), wholly musician, or wholly painter. It seems possible that the great English art may not be the art of words. His eye is stimulated by the colour of the of the clotning (clothing), of the pageantry. his ear by the sound of words spoken aloud. For books were read aloud. " Prtitachrd (Pritchard)" wrote "read aloud the ..... They read aloud and the Faery Queen." Every word was given sharpness and substance by the speaking voice. And the lute, the cithern, the old full bodied instrument that still stands on a
ches (chest), hgave (gave) lilt, rhythm, melody to the word.
"Hardly one lighter or boat in hree (three) that had the goods of a house in it , but there was a pair of virginals in
it" observed in 1666 when the people of London were loading their goods onto boats to escape from the fire of London. His mind the was full of undifferentiated words, ole (old) words and new words; French and Latin. No grammar bound them tightly together. They were elastic; they could be danced to and sung to. But they could not follow the pace of the
spea ing (speaking) voice.
then in the is like a half articulate monster rising from the depths of silnce (silence) hung with the weeds and pearls of the deep sea in

he the writer has been so long submerged. We cannot read the ; nor leave it undread (unread). It is a poem without a plot; the metre, casting its regular fling of sound, comes to ground to (too) evenly, too solidly, unlike who goes on, simply, directly, at an even pace. Great groups, composed, arranged, come together with the
orest (forest) for back rg und (background). must have seen Italian pictures; or was it natural then to make compositions even in words? The Knihgyts (knights) the ldaies (ladies) and the ogres pass away amble their way through the glades and become one with the clouds. Like a lcliund ([cloud?]) the words move up and down; furst (first) lulling the ear then cloying the ear. It has the sweetness of a dream; something cut adrift from the rough rish (Irish) land which lay outside; it has freshness, it has csharpness (sharpness). It is the thing itself; it is the original design, from which and
mad (made) their copies.
Latimer heard them. He raged. His is the voice of the new
